resources.string: An Othello game always starts off in this position shown; with two discs of each colour intersecting each other diagonally. The top right disc is always black from either players sitting view.

First move always goes to black, in order to make a legal move the player must place their colour on one of the empty squares on the board. The disc must directly sandwich one or more opposing colours, in either horizontal, vertical or diagonal directions. This is then followed by the flipping of the sandwiched discs. If a player has no moves available to them. Their turn is forfeit until they have an available move.

The game continues on until the players either run out of spaces on the board or there are no valid moves left. The winner is decided by the number of points or pieces he or she has. If a player runs out of time, they automatically lose, regardless of accumulated points

No one like being told what to do

Good thing you only need a few simple rules to quickly start playing your own games of Othello
Just Swipe right to get started
is one of superiority\n\nOutwit your opponent and take control of the game board by outnumbering your opponents pieces with your own.

Players take turns placing counters on an 8x8 board. The idea here is to sandwich tokens and flip them.\n\nOnce you get a few games under your belt it will become fairly easy to understand and you should find yourself planning strategies against your opponent. Remember openings and endgame play is equally important.

Black/bottom always goes first

 You may only place your piece beside an opponent's piece

 Flip as many pieces as you can by sandwiching opponents pieces between your own (in either horizontal, vertical or diagonal directions)

 If you can't make a move your turn is forfeit

By having the most counters on the board when there are no more moves left for either player.\n\n Beware: If you have opted for a timed game and run out of time - You will lose regardless of your score.
